headline: OK place to work
pros: May good opportunities to learn.
cons: I wish the company was doing better.

headline: Good work environment
pros: Good work atmosphere, opportunities to move around company to a different position if you want, a lot of smart people, good balance of work/life allowed, ample vacation time, plenty of opportunities for learning and people willing to teach
cons: As with any large company, changes can be bureaucratic when they should not be. Some things seem to be done certain ways just because they have always been done a certain way. Definitely not a small company or startup atmosphere.

headline: A company with great technology that can't seem to hire and retain excellent executive leadership.
pros: AMD has great technology and is consistently on the leading edge, technologically.
cons: The internal systems are very immature & the senior leadership is weak.  It's no fun competing in a duopoly when you only have 10% market share.

headline: A company with great technology that can't seem to hire and retain excellent executive leadership.
pros: AMD has great technology and is consistently on the leading edge, technologically.
cons: The internal systems are very immature & the senior leadership is weak.  It's no fun competing in a duopoly when you only have 10% market share.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Mostly good people.  As with most companies, especially large ones, your manager creates most of the environment that makes your job pleasant or difficult.
cons: Typical politics of a large company

headline: Laid back environment in a fast pace CPU industry
pros:
Managers are really flexible in terms of work hours. "Benefits" and recognitions can vary greatly depending on the project you are working on. 
Lots of opportunities to go on business trips which are as good as paid vacation at AMD if you are lucky enough to work on important project.
cons: Criteria and standards for performance and achievement rating is a joke

headline: A big corporate company with small company infrastructure
pros: Offer the best health care package (medical, vision, dental, etc.)
cons: Not enough support for IT support when you have IT issue.

headline: My experience at AMD was overly good.
pros: AMD offers competitive benefits and professional development.
cons: Employees are not valued and compensation is unbalanced.

headline: Challenging, fast-paced.
pros: Uses latest software language, tools, and configuration management. Exposure to latest tools and technology in software engineering is quite good.
cons: Too much coordination between different teams, quite daunting for an engineer who wants to focus on technical or engineering matters. Can do better in project management.

headline: Generally satisfying, somewhat stymied as far as growth
pros: The base compensation is average to above average, and there tends to be good respect for work-life balance. There are some really great people working there, and pockets of support for professional and personal growth.
cons: While AMD talks a good talk about professional growth, I found myself blocked a bit as I tried to develop my career. There's a tendency to pigeonhole good people into their role, and while it makes sense, it's a frustrating place to be. The company changes direction in messaging, marketing, and focus often, making it very hard to really maintain a consistent story. The overall experience is decent, but lacking when it comes to really developing one's career.

headline: Leadership is a buzzword, not a philosophy or goal.
pros: AMD is a good place to learn about complex semiconductor products in all aspects.  There are good opportunities in design, testing, and product definition.
cons: The senior leadership is all about doing what someone else has already done.  Developing new IP, or new products for new areas is not what AMD is about.  If you are interested in any kind of marketing, don't join AMD.

headline: Cutting edge technology
pros: As an recent college graduate you will gain exposure into all aspects of ASIC design. Good luck with your search.
cons: Long hours affects work life balance.

headline: Decent company, not leading-edge
pros: Fair salary, reasonable growth opprtunities
cons: Matrixed organization is somewhat chaotic

headline: 8 year former employee
pros:
1) The people - engineers (hardware, software and debug) were fantastic people.  Lower management as well were all hard working and conscientious.  I would gladly call everyone I worked with my friend.
2) Work life balance - Other than bringup/launch times, plenty of leeway was given to do the things that we all want to do: go to school with kids, eat dinner at home with family, go the the gym, etc.
3) Doing what you want - I was firm enough with my manager that when I said I was going to do something, I meant it.  So, when I wanted to learn something new, I was able to go do it.
cons:
1) Squeaky wheel syndrome - I was squeaky, so I got more grease than those around me, but they don't give you ANYTHING that you don't demand.  They really should reward people for their effort, not for their complaining.
2) Management sucks - I was there for 7 or 8 rounds of layoffs and I kept watching the talent walk out the door while the managers and PMs filled their ranks with "architects" and fellows.

headline: Review from a new employee perspective
pros: + Major market player in computer hardware
cons:
+ Different teams do not communicate. Very insular environment. 
+ Knowledge sharing...does not exist. 
+ Compensation and bonus lacking.
+ Excessive hiring of contract workers. Hire quality people, pay and promote. Many other reviews have been negative on this aspect.

headline: Used to be great, deteriorating culture....
author_position: Member of Technical Staff Design Engineer
pros:
(1) The company still has some very smart engineers.
(2) Decent work-life balance, but that is changing.
(3) Employees starting their careers get a chance to learn a lot compared to bigger companies.
cons:
(1) This is not a company to join for long term growth prospects. The most productive period of an engineer in AMD is the first 3-4 years from joining.
(2) The senior management is increasingly adopting an engineer unfriendly approach (think of Google, then reverse it). As a result, the best and brightest are increasingly calling it quits, and it seems the management does not care. There is no effort whatsoever to either retain existing talent or to attract talent.
(3) When experienced engineers quit, they are largely replaced by Program Managers (or people with equivalent skill sets), causing a severe dearth in technical leadership.
(4) There is no support for any out-of-the-box thinking at all, which is what made AMD a household name to begin with.

headline: Poor management, top heavy, too many talkers, not rewarding doers
author_position: Member of Technical Staff ASIC Design
pros: Ok salary, not bad experience
cons:
Too many life time employees, from managers to engineers, who have very narrow view
Compensations always go to old timers first, not based on contribution

headline: no comments
pros: working time is very flexible
cons: company performance is very volatile

headline: Good
pros:
Good Base Salary although the bonus plan is not good.
Nice people to work with and nice campus to work at.
Great weather year round.
cons:
Bonus plan is defficient.
Stock option plan is very small

headline: Excellent technical leaders. Innovative technology happens in AMD
pros:
Flexibility of work type. You can shape your career as you want. 
Management will provide the opportunity
cons:
Your furture is in your reporting managers hand. He can misuse the performance rating feedback.
No one in upper management, will question his rating.  There is a repeated misuse of the "performance rating" system.

headline: Challenge and benefit a lot in the cutting-edge semiconductor project
pros: Knowledge about  cutting-edge IC design and most advanced technology based tape out experience, could work on bigger chips like CPU/GPU fusion chips.
cons: The Asic design flow from front-end to back-end is such sophisticated that most engineers just could not see the whole develop map of real tape out.

headline: My work experience is very enriching and full of good memory
pros: The best reason to work is AMD is because it's a not a cut-throat environment and you can have a work life balance. Everybody is doing their best and help each other as a team. As the result you're inspired to come to work and do your best
cons: The downside of working in not a large company compared is more often we have less monetary reward compared to bigger company.

headline: Exciting work on cutting edge technology
pros:
Work on Latest technology hardware and software
Plenty of resources and good support
Good salary and other benifits
Competent co workers
cons:
There are very less chances of foreign travel for training/other purposes
Quality of work for across different sites of same team differs

headline: A good beginning for a career that has some dull moments.
pros: Valuable experience for someone new to the industry.  Gives a lot of knowledge about how both a software and hardware company operates.  AMD has been in the field for such a long time, it has made a name for itself and knows what its doing.  The company has a very "lax" setting, and all the engineers are chill.
cons: The work can be pretty monotonous, especially for new hires/interns.  It's a daily grind of doing somewhat mundane but essential tasks.  The pay is considerably low to competitors, employees tend to be kind of anti-social as they all do their own thing.  It's somewhat hard to thrive for someone new.

headline: Fulfilling opportunities to work with leading edge technology and pursue my own career path.
pros: Benefits are great, work life balance is emphasised.
cons: Large company can make communication across teams challenging.

headline: Good benefits, fair pay, lots of engineers
pros: Good benefits, fair pay, excellent campus
cons: lots of engineers, manager determines way too much of personal experience

headline: it is good for step stone
pros: a famous IT company. It is nice to put it on your resume
cons: too many politics.  you may have trouble if you file some critical EPR

headline: Great People
pros: I am a long time employee and love the culture
cons: Budgets are always so constrained.

headline: Good culture if you don't mind big companies. No respect for Software Engineers.
author_position: Member of Technical Staff Software Engineer
pros:
* Lower management generally fair and do a pretty good job of looking out for the best interest of the DEVs and the products
* Pretty good pay and benefits
* Good culture (compared to some other big companies)
* Some really smart & talented people, especially in the software group
* Relatively stable. While not universally true, downsizing typically affects lower-performers
cons:
* No respect for Software Engineers
* Upper management out of touch with software engineering ethos
* Culture changing somewhat for the worse
* Constant pressure from management to hire _somebody_ rather than wait for excellent devs
* Ridiculous software process (counting lines of code and bugs fixed to measure team "success")
* Objectionable stance on patents (constant pressure to submit _something_ just so the company will have more in its portfolio)

headline: A relaxed environment with good fellow employees
pros: Most employees are friendly. The workload, most of the time, is typical of a large company. Performing at average is not too difficult.
cons: Management direction and technical knowledge needs to be better. Management needs to move to allow the advancement of talented young employees. More accountability among management and employees.

headline: Very good place to work
pros:
1. Very good work culture.
2. Good learning path
3. Friendly management
cons: Management should work close with junior employess

headline: too much team politics and finger pointing; poor management; mgmt favoritism
Average engineering experience
pros: work and life balance. People are easy going. The task assignment was very clear. The achivement was recognized well. No much peer-pressure. Communication and information sharing are good.
cons: rewards from stock was low. Lack of new ideas. Some mistakes had to be repeated multiple times until finally solving. Salary raising was kind of slow. Office location was not very good.

headline: Very competitive environment, rather difficult place to work
pros: Salary ranges were good. Many good colleagues. Challenging problems to solve, and a good environment for generating solutions, at least in the EDA tools space.
cons: Understaffed in many areas. Management did not seem to be in touch with the difficulties of the day to day work going on. The environment of multi-site splitting of projects and staff made ongoing cooperation difficult. A feeling of a very reactive company to attempt to fill the needs of the marketplace, especially trying to catch up to competition.  A culture based on reward and recognition and individual accomplishments, which translated to a culture where sharing of knowledge seemed to be restricted.

headline: Glad I was there, glad I left.
pros: Well paying job where you can get lots of experience quickly
cons: Company is constantly changing focus, making jobs unstable

headline: Culture changed
pros: Great engineers with a lot of capability
cons: Too much senior management and can't make decisions

headline: Long succesful career at AMD
pros: Growth opportunities have been available to me over the years

headline: Once a great place to work, but no more ...

Challenging work from the technical side of things
Good benefits
Beautiful campus

Incompetent upper management
Only the best for management, and the least for the technical staff.
Management refuses to admit when they are wrong, and will sink the company rather than change.

cons: High employee turnover. Management leads by consensus. Most of the people responsible for past success are long gone. IBM managers are invading, trying to harness the culture 2005 that is also long gone.

I have to take some verbal abuses from my manager just because I was busy on my work and few minutes later in one of the meeting. Manager are clueless in what the engineers are doing but present himself as experts in managing which is useless in daily work.

cons:

2. Extremely process-oriented, no-technical work. Most of the time you don't understand why are you doing something.
3. Bad work environment.

headline: Great Place - a Small family

headline: Good co workers, managemt is some what lacking

headline: Not so great

headline: It is ok
pros: Easy going company . They will always remain a no 2 company
cons: Very slow company with no direction

headline: A company with a very complex model / tough tall order BUT has the greatest collection of good people in the industry.
pros:
People in AMD are downright good hearted people with brilliant minds. 
I never ever felt I have to always watch my back. I had not met a Micro Manager here. Takes forever to hire (I've put in so many long hours) but they know to hire those who they can trust. 
Very flexible so long am at work at 10am. I have to take kids to day care. Mgt understands parent duties very strongly.
Management encourages use of vacation/time off.
cons:
Promotions take forever. You know other companies are always eyeing AMD people so one's always fighting the thought of moving or staying. 
Constant change in leadership

headline: Great place to work.
pros:
-Flexible hours (core hours between 10am and 4pm, you can come in early to leave at 4, or come in at 10 to leave late.
-Great benefits (full-time get 90% dental - max $2,000, full drug, full massage, physio, chiro, orthotics, etc - max $500 each)
-Very friendly.
-Great place to learn.
cons:
-Located in Markham (horrible traffic).
-Small percentage of women.

headline: most people around you are nice to work with
pros: most people around you are nice to work with; good working environment; innovative products; free gym; on-site cafeteria; up to 4-week vacation annually;
cons: being the underdog almost all the time, the company constantly in surviving mode, which means layoffs, budget cuts, pay cuts or freezes, priority changes, etc.

headline: The executives appear to be lost when it comes to fixing the products and the process to deliver the products.
pros: Very competitive compensation packages.  Many of the positions require working on the cutting edge of technology, and can be very challenging.
cons: The company does not believe in investing in their people.  Attendance to seminars and conferences are treated as perks rather than opportunities for staff to upgrade their skills and abilities.  The company's market niche is being eroded at both the high end and low end by its competitors, and so far the product roadmap does not appear to be capable to address this situation.

headline: Good experience as an intern. Kind bunch of people and very fun.
pros:

- quarterly team events

cons: - could be boring if you wind up with a bad team

headline: Great people, bad strategy, minimal job security
pros: Great people to learn from and work with.
cons: Long hours. No job security as the jobs are being shippped out to Asia.

headline: Pretty good environment to work in. Easily get bored.
pros:
- A great way to get your feet wet for beginner and understanding of semiconductor industry.
- There're some up and down time of the work cycle.
cons:
- Don't find much opportunity for personal improvement and career path
- Work could be repetitive and boring after a short while
- The computer/ microprocessor market is extremely tough these days. Company is struggling to survive.
